website.siteDescription: HGOR is a company that is focused on designing great places for people, places which support clear returns on investment and provide a stewardship ethic for future generations.

items.title: Spanx Headquarters
items.body:
Spanx Headquarters

At approximately 8,000 total square feet, the roof garden space sits atop the third floor of the building, adjacent the interior dining space. Designed to accommodate a large event of up to five hundred users, the space also breaks down into smaller spaces which accommodate intimate conversations and gatherings. With a custom serpentine Ipe garden bench and platform edge, the space is organized around a central synthetic turf lawn panel.

Outdoor dining is accommodated under a large steel canopy, designed with a rough urban feel and appointed and finished with custom drapery, ceiling fans, heaters and string lights. Keeping with  contemporary flexible workplace trends, employees are offered multiple choices, from outdoor covered work spaces, a private raised stage platform looking back at the dining space, and a custom Ipe shadowbox wall surround with a counter overlooking the Streets of Buckhead. Two sides of the space are surrounded with metal panels and faux planted green walls designed to frame the space and create a more intimate scale for tenants to utilize and engage with within the central amenity.

items.title: Levine Center for the Arts
items.body:
Levine Center for the Arts

Armed with a budget and clear objectives, HGOR redesigned this half-acre plaza which serves as the center point of Charlotte’s new arts district. Food vendors, art and performance space and both fixed and flexible seating space offer visual variety and distinct vantage points to add to an active sense of place. Simple, durable materials, low-maintenance materials are used throughout to provide a calm, comfortable environment.

items.title: Westside Park at Bellwood Quarry
items.body:
Westside Park at Bellwood Quarry

The City of Atlanta partnered with HGOR to master plan the entire park and design the first phase, which will include immaculate park gateways, dynamic play zone, the Proctor Creek connection and parking. When complete the park will showcase a grand high overlook with spectacular views back to the Atlanta skyline and other prospects, a stage, architectural follies, a community farm and a braided stormwater system. At nearly 300 acres, Westside Park at Bellwood Quarry will eventually be Atlanta’s biggest park

items.title: Children's Healthcare of Atlanta Center for Advanced Pediatrics
items.body:
Children's Healthcare of Atlanta Center for Advanced Pediatrics

A new eight-story pediatrics center engages a one and a half acre garden space in Brookhaven, Georgia. The landscape, inspired by the Piedmont region of Georgia, contains a fountain, pavilion, custom trellis and a large scale sculpture. The garden spaces provide a variety of place experiences for respite, socializing, eating, working and large gathering events. In addition, a 10,000sf stormwater bio-infiltration collects and treats storm water prior to downstream release.

items.title: All Saints' Episcopal Church
items.body:
All Saints' Episcopal Church

All Saints’ Episcopal Church’s campus, dating from 1901, includes both historic and new structures, each dedicated to the service of the parish and the surrounding community. HGOR led the design effort to enhance the design of the lower courtyard and connections to campus facilities. The resulting plan allows the campus grounds to have flexibility for numerous events held each year as well provide a safe and tranquil space for visitors.

items.title: Mercer University South Campus
items.body:
Mercer University South Campus

Mercer University asked HGOR to assist in visioning pedestrian and aesthetic upgrades in the area comprising the South Campus Athletics Precinct and Entry. The opening of a new football stadium in the Fall of 2013 dramatically shifted previous circulation patterns and has resulted in an increase of visitors approaching campus from the south via Mercer Boulevard.

Recommendations included rerouting and connecting walks, providing enhanced seating and viewing opportunities for baseball and volleyball, enhancements to the stadium arrival and transforming a detention facility into usable green space with an infiltration based rain garden.

The plan recommendations were endorsed by the University who retained HGOR to further develop the recommendations for immediate implementation. Construction began in the Spring of 2014 with scheduled completion by August of the same year.

items.filename: UGA Reed Plaza at Sanford Stadium (38) - Copy.jpg
items.title: University of Georgia Reed Plaza at Sanford Stadium
items.body:
University of Georgia Reed Plaza at Sanford Stadium

At the heart of UGA, patrons and students enjoy a multi-function amenity at the campus’ historic Sanford Stadium. Supporting both game day events and non-event days, the design transforms over three acres of unorganized vehicular-dominated space to a pedestrian oriented mall connecting East Campus Road and the Tate Student Center.

On game day, the plaza will serve as a comfortable, vibrant, lower-level concourse with new restroom facilities, a twenty-one window concession building and several areas for freestanding vendor opportunities. On non-game days, the plaza will become a public space for various student life activities.

Received a 2012 Merit Award from the Georgia Chapter of the American Society of Landscape Architects.

.

items.title: Georgia Tech McCamish Pavilion
items.body:
Georgia Tech McCamish Pavilion

Dubbed the “Thrillerdome” for its many dramatic last-minute finishes, this 9,000+ seat arena dates to 1956 and is one of the nation’s best college facilities. HGOR worked in conjunction with sports architecture firm Populous to connect the eight-acre site more dynamically with the rest of campus and the surrounding community. Located in lively West Midtown, the new entry design energizes student, visitor and VIP gateways, echoing pedestrian-friendly neighborhood streetscapes. Environmentally advanced elements such as integrated stormwater filtration offer serene green space amid an urban setting.

items.title: Mercer University Cruz Plaza
items.body:
Mercer University Cruz Plaza

Mercer University wanted to redefine its central campus quad and green space as more inviting, inclusive and integrated. HGOR was tapped to create a comprehensive master open space plan to guide future exterior development. As the visual center of campus, the timeless, understated design emphasizes a sense of arrival, and provides a flexibility activity space for student life. Elements include fountains, brick walkways, gathering and seating spaces, significant landscaping improvements and a prominent water feature. In addition, a 2,200-pound bronze bear statue has been relocated, becoming a focal point of the Plaza’s design.

items.title: Berry College Kilpatrick Commons
items.body:
Berry College Kilpatrick Commons

In conjunction with the expansion of the College’s Krannert Student Center, Kilpatrick Commons was conceived as an outdoor dining experience and campus reception area. Situated at the intersection of major campus circulation routes and a large open space, the design creates a unique destination while resolving significant grade changes and through circulation. Drawing from a mountain vernacular appropriate to its location in north Georgia, the design utilizes a cascading stream to link upper and lower levels while pedestrian circulation is routed above creating an enclosed mountain “grotto” effect. The contrast between the large open commons and the dining grotto is accentuated with a defined bridge underpass at seating level.
